{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} <!-- Please see talk page before messing with the names again. Thank you! --> {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Richardson family murders | image = | caption = | location = [[Medicine Hat]], [[Alberta]], Canada | coordinates = | date = April 23, 2006 | time = | timezone = | type = Triple murder | fatalities = 3 | survivors = | victims = Marc Richardson, Debra Richardson, Tyler Jacob Richardson | injuries = | perps = Jasmine Richardson, Jeremy Allan Steinke | weapons = Knife }} Three members of the Richardson family were murdered in [[Medicine Hat]], [[Alberta]], Canada in April 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/three-bodies-found-medicine-hat-alta-home/article20410851/|title=Three bodies found Medicine Hat, Alta., home}}</ref> The murders were planned and committed by the family's 12-year-old daughter Jasmine<ref name="sutton16">{{Cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/news-life/jasmine-richardson-walks-free-a-decade-after-as-a-12yearold-she-and-werewolf-boyfriend-massacred-her-family/news-story/f826a2b4efb359bd02b53c4066234bae |title=The girl who massacred her own family walks free after 10 years |last=Sutton |first=Candace |date=August 21, 2016 |website=News.Com.Au |access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w86BBAAAQBAJ |title=The Best of American True Crime |last=Hunter |first=Grey |publisher=Lulu Press, Inc |year=2014 |isbn=9781312377769 |editor-last=Hegde |editor-first=Nischal |page=30 |language=en }}</ref><ref name="chalmers09">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WYDQwDvXz9MC |title=Inside the Mind of a Teen Killer |last=Chalmers |first=Phil |publisher=Thomas Nelson Inc |year=2009 |isbn=9781595551528 |location=Nashville, Tenn. |page=162 |language=en |oclc=213845230}}</ref> and her 23-year-old boyfriend Jeremy Steinke, now going by the name Jackson May.<ref name=csun>[http://www.calgarysun.com/2012/01/11/mass-medicine-hat-killer-jeremy-steinke-changes-name-seeks-appeal "Mass Medicine Hat killer Jeremy Steinke changes name, seeks appeal"], ''http://www.calgarysun.com/'', January 12, 2012.</ref> Jasmine and Steinke were each convicted on three counts of first-degree murder. The daughter, who had turned 13 before being convicted, is thought to be the youngest person in Canada ever convicted of multiple first-degree murder counts.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|title=Children who kill children: 6 high-profile cases|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/children-who-kill-children-6-high-profile-cases-1.1322603|publisher=[[CBC News]]|location=|date=September 3, 2013|access-date=February 13, 2016|quote=When a 13-year-old Alberta girl was found guilty in the 2006 murder of her eight-year-old brother and her parents, it was believed she was the youngest person in Canada to be convicted of multiple counts of first-degree murder.}}</ref> Her 10-year sentence was completed on May 6, 2016.<ref name="sutton16" />
==Discovery== At 1:00 p.m. on April 23, 2006, the bodies of husband Marc Richardson, 42, and wife Debra, 48, were found in the basement of their home,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesudburystar.com/2008/06/24/do-youth-sentences-fit-the-crime-comment-on-this-story|title=Do youth sentences fit the crime? (comment on this story)|last=Punch|first=Rachel|work=The Sudbury Star|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref> and the body of their son Tyler Jacob,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/net-holds-dark-hints-on-slayings/article1098702/|title=Net holds dark hints on slayings|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> 8, was discovered upstairs.<ref name="Triple murder shocks city">{{cite news|first=Leanne |last=Dohy |author= |url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=c3f96856-92e2-40da-b431-2a42761ae015 |title=Triple murder shocks city |work=[[Calgary Herald]] |page=A.1. |date=April 24, 2006 |accessdate=June 19, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140425062118/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=c3f96856-92e2-40da-b431-2a42761ae015 |archivedate=April 25, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>Sherri Zickefoose, Tony Seskus and Robert Remington, [http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=4a05be55-e965-4494-bc83-1079462aa6e9 "Road to a massacre"], ''National Post'', April 29, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319225636/http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=4a05be55-e965-4494-bc83-1079462aa6e9 |date=March 19, 2014 }}</ref><ref>Zickefoose, Sherri, [http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=96e72579-9f5a-498f-9040-2588431bffd4&k=9921 "Bodies of slain family flown to Ontario for funeral"], ''National Post'', May 1, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060514034236/http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/story.html?id=96e72579-9f5a-498f-9040-2588431bffd4&k=9921 |date=May 14, 2006 }}</ref> Absent from the home at that time was the couple's 12-year-old daughter Jasmine.<ref name="Triple murder shocks city" /><ref name="cbc1">[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/04/24/medhatmurder060424.html "12-year-old charged in Medicine Hat"], ''CBC.ca'', April 24, 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809075419/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/04/24/medhatmurder060424.html |date=August 9, 2007 }}</ref> For a time it was feared that she might have also been a victim, but she was arrested the following day in the community of [[Leader, Saskatchewan]], about {{convert|130|km|mi|0}} away, with her 23-year-old boyfriend Jeremy Allan Steinke. Both were charged with the three murders.<ref name="cbc1" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=df022f89-4ada-4be1-80dc-4df1090096e3&k=46676 |title=More charges possible in triple murders |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060522051613/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=df022f89-4ada-4be1-80dc-4df1090096e3&k=46676 |archivedate=May 22, 2006 |df= }}</ref> Later, on May 3, 2006, Steinke's friend Kacy Lancaster, 19, was charged with being an [[Accessory (legal term)|accessory]], for driving them away in her pickup truck later in the day and for disposing of evidence.<ref name="journal1">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311135430/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=6e1b930e-4c3c-4a7f-947e-546c5b16fc92&k=7316 Third person charged], ''Edmonton Journal'', May 4, 2006</ref>
==Motive== According to friends of Jasmine, the girl's parents had punished her for dating Steinke due to the age disparity.<ref name=calgarysun1>Breakenridge, Dave, [http://calsun.canoe.ca/News/Alberta/2006/04/28/1554824-sun.html "Pre-teen's tryst 'gross' Friends of 12-year-old accused killer disapproved of boyfriend, 23"], ''Calgary Sun'', April 28, 2006.</ref> Her friends had also criticized their relationship.<ref name=calgarysun1 /> Shortly after her arrest, Steinke asked her to marry him, and she agreed.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/2007/06/30/girl_on_trial_for_murder_agreed_to_marry_lover.html Girl on trial for murder agreed to marry lover], ''Toronto Star'', June 30, 2007.</ref> According to friends of Steinke, he told them he was a 300-year-old [[werewolf]].<ref>[http://www.citytv.com/calgary/news_28516.aspx "Mother Of Accused Family Killer Speaks Out Against Vilification Of Son"], ''CityTV Calgary'', April 26, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209043948/http://www.citytv.com/calgary/news_28516.aspx |date=February 9, 2011 }}</ref> He allegedly told his friends that he liked the taste of blood, and wore a small vial of blood around his neck.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120723183534/http://www.dailyheraldtribune.com/Z04_00achilllingstories04.lasso "Chilling stories emerge; Mother of accused in triple slaying denies her son was a werewolf"], ''Daily Herald-Tribune'', April 28, 2006.</ref> He also had a user account at the VampireFreaks.com website.<ref>Algar, Selim, [https://nypost.com/2006/04/29/vampire-blog-an-eerie-site/ ‘VAMPIRE’ BLOG AN EERIE SITE], ''New York Post'', April 29, 2006.</ref> The girl had a page at the same site, leading to speculation they met there.<ref>Reynolds, Richard, [http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/accused-killer-12-linked-to-goth-site/2006/04/27/1145861490145.html "Accused killer, 12, linked to goth site"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', April 28, 2006.</ref> However, an acquaintance of Steinke later said the couple actually met at a [[punk rock]] show in early 2006.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060501230346/http://www.630ched.com/news/news_local.cfm?cat=7428109912&rem=36376&red=80110923aPBIny&wids=410&gi=1&gm=news_local.cfm "Medicine Hat Murder Suspects Appear in Court"], ''630 CHED AM'', April 26, 2006.</ref> The couple were also found to be communicating at [[Nexopia]], a popular website for young Canadians.<ref name="nexopia">Walton, Dawn, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/net-holds-dark-hints-on-slayings/article1098702/ "Net holds dark hints on slayings"], ''The Globe and Mail'', April 26, 2006.</ref> Various messages they sent to each other were available to the public, before the accounts were removed by Nexopia staff.<ref name="nexopia" />
Jasmine's user page, under the name "runawaydevil", falsely said she was 15 and ended with the text "Welcome to my tragic end".<ref>Johnsrude, Larry, [http://www.canada.com/globaltv/edmonton/news/story.html?id=b8a9c828-16ea-4f12-85b9-e0dc78feed16&k=26559 "Goths say Medicine Hat killings give them bad name"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311135826/http://www.canada.com/globaltv/edmonton/news/story.html?id=b8a9c828-16ea-4f12-85b9-e0dc78feed16&k=26559 |date=March 11, 2007 }}, ''Edmonton Journal'', April 26, 2006.</ref> Just hours prior to committing the murders, Steinke and some friends reportedly watched the 1994 film ''[[Natural Born Killers]]'', about a young couple who go on a violent killing spree. Steinke told his friends that he and his girlfriend should go about their plans in a similar manner, but without sparing her young brother.<ref>[http://solvevingamystery.blogspot.com/2009/10/steinke-girlfriend-smiled-at-murder.html Steinke, girlfriend smiled at murder coverage: Witness]</ref> Steinke also said to an undercover officer: 'You ever watch the movie ''Natural Born Killers''?... I think that's the best love story of all time...'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=ce5c240d-8254-4e64-a757-d00e501d5fea|title=Steinke: "You ever watch the movie Natural Born killers?"|accessdate=June 2, 2010|date=November 19, 2008|author=The Calgary Herald|publisher=CanWest MediaWorks Publications Inc.}}</ref>
==Legal outcome== ===Daughter=== Under the [[Youth Criminal Justice Act]], Jasmine's name could no longer be published in [[Canada]] after she became a suspect. Under the same act, twelve is the youngest possible age at which a person can be charged with a crime; convicts who were under fourteen years of age at the time they committed a crime cannot be sentenced as adults, and cannot be given more than a ten-year sentence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=29d18d62-f3bd-40be-a554-7b8eea81458d |title=If convicted, girl would be free in 10 years |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813110622/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=29d18d62-f3bd-40be-a554-7b8eea81458d |archivedate=August 13, 2014 |df= }}</ref> On July 9, 2007, Jasmine, who had by then turned 13, was found guilty of three counts of first-degree murder in the killings.<ref name=cbc2>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2007/07/09/med-hat.html|title=Medicine Hat girl guilty of first-degree murder|work=cbc.ca|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=July 9, 2007|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222112529/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2007/07/09/med-hat.html|archive-date=December 22, 2007|accessdate=February 13, 2016}}</ref> She is believed to be the youngest person ever convicted of a multiple murder in Canada.<ref name=cbc2 />
On November 8, 2007, she was sentenced to the maximum penalty of ten years' imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2007/11/08/girl-sentence.html|title=Teen gets maximum sentence for Medicine Hat killings|work=cbc.ca|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=November 8, 2007|accessdate=November 8, 2007}}</ref> Her sentence included credit for eighteen months already spent in custody, to be followed by four years in a psychiatric institution and four-and-a-half years under conditional supervision in the community.
In September 2011, Jasmine began attending classes at [[Mount Royal University]] in Calgary, Alberta during the final years of her sentence.<ref>[http://www.gather.com/viewArticlePF.action?articleId=281474980423951 Child Murderer Facing November Release]</ref> She was released from a ten-year sentence at a psychiatric hospital in the fall of 2011, and in October 2012 it was reported her rehabilitation was going well, and she expressed remorse for her actions that experts considered genuine.<ref>{{cite web|title=Medicine Hat teen killer sentence reviewed|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/medicine-hat-teen-killer-sentence-reviewed-1.1262255|publisher=CBC News|date=October 1, 2012}}</ref>
In May 2016 her sentence was completed, and she was freed of any further court-ordered conditions, restrictions or supervision after a final sentence review on May 6, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Labby|first=Bryan|title=J.R., who stabbed family to death with boyfriend at age 12, is free after 10-year sentence|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/jr-medicine-hat-murders-steinke-sentence-review-1.3568118|accessdate=May 6, 2016|publisher=CBC News|date=May 6, 2016}}</ref>
===Jeremy Steinke=== Steinke allegedly admitted to the murder of the parents in conversation with an undercover police officer while in custody. He was tried in November 2008 and found guilty by a jury on three counts of first-degree murder for the killings of the three Richardson victims.<ref>{{cite web|title=Steinke allegedly admitted to murder|url=http://calgary.ctvnews.ca/steinke-allegedly-admitted-to-murder-1.343878|publisher=CTVCalgary.ca|date=November 18, 2008}}</ref> On December 15, 2008, Steinke was sentenced to three life sentences, one for each first-degree murder count. The sentences are to be served concurrently, and Steinke will be eligible for parole after serving twenty-five years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=67c05ce9-ef5b-491e-ae51-a705cef3b0e7|title=Steinke gets life in triple-murder|publisher=''[[Calgary Herald]]''|date=December 16, 2008|accessdate=July 24, 2009}}</ref>
===Kacy Lancaster=== The accessory to murder charge against the couple's friend Kacy Lancaster was dropped, and she pleaded guilty to an obstruction charge in Medicine Hat provincial court. She received one year house arrest as part of the plea bargain, and was ordered to refrain from drugs and alcohol.
== See also ==
* [[Barbecue murders]] * [[Freeman family murders]] * [[Lin family murders]] * ''[[Deadly Women]]'', an American television show that featured an episode with a segment about the Richardson family murders * ''[[Killer Kids]]'', an American-Canadian documentary show that featured an episode with a segment about the Richardson family murders

Ortaklari (1951-56) *Erpak Vap. Ithalkat Ihracat, (1956-59) *Zeki v. Ziya Son (1959-61) | Ship operator =*Bugsier Reederei und Bergungs AG (1912-45) *Rose Line Ltd (1945-47) *S Hannan & Co (1947-51) *Azize Arkan v. Ortaklari (1951-56) *Erpak Vap. Ithalkat Ihracat, (1956-59) *Zeki v. Ziya Son (1959-61) | Ship registry =*{{Flagicon|German Empire}} Hamburg (1912-19) *{{Flagicon|Weimar Republic|civil}} Hamburg (1919-33) *{{Flagicon|Nazi Germany}} Bremerhaven (1933-45) *{{Flagicon|United Kingdom|civil}} London (1945-47) *{{Flagicon|Turkey}} Turkey (1947-61) | Ship route = | Ship ordered = | Ship builder = Stettiner Oderwerke AG, | Ship original cost = | Ship yard number = | Ship way number = | Ship laid down = | Ship launched = 1912 | Ship completed = | Ship commissioned = | Ship decommissioned = | Ship christened = | Ship acquired = | Ship maiden voyage = | Ship in service = | Ship out of service = January 1961 | Ship identification =*Code Letters RSMN (1912-34) *{{ICS|Romeo}}{{ICS|Sierra}}{{ICS|Mike}}{{ICS|November}} *Code Letters DHFJ (1934-45) *{{ICS|Delta}}{{ICS|Hotel}}{{ICS|Foxtrot}}{{ICS|Juliet}} *Code Letters GFXT (1945-51) *{{ICS|Golf}}{{ICS|Foxtrot}}{{ICS|X-ray}}{{ICS|Tango}} *United Kingdom Official Number 180639 (1945-51) | Ship fate = Sank | Ship status = | Ship notes = }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = | Ship class = Coaster | Ship tonnage =*{{GRT|535}} *{{NRT|266}}<!-- *x,xxx [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]]--> | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|165|ft|8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|28|ft|6|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship height = | Ship draught = | Ship depth = {{convert|11|ft|5|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship registry = | Ship power = Compound steam engine | Ship propulsion = Screw propellor | Ship speed = <!--{{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}--> | Ship capacity = | Ship crew = | Ship notes = | Ship armament = }} |}
'''''Dollart''''' was a {{GRT|535|link=off}} [[coastal trading vessel|coaster]] that was built in 1912 by [[Stettiner Oderwerke]] [[Aktiengesellschaft|AG]], [[Stettin]], [[Germany]] for German owners. She was seized by the Allies in May 1945, passed to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) and was renamed '''''Empire Constancy'''''. In 1947, she was sold into merchant service and renamed '''''Polzeath'''''. In 1951, she was sold to [[Turkey]] and renamed '''''Meltem'''''. Further sales saw her renamed '''''Yener 9''''' in 1956 and '''''Yarasli''''' in 1959. She went missing in the [[Ionian Sea]] in January 1961.
==Description== The ship was built in 1912 by [[Stettiner Oderwerke]], [[Stettin]].<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref>
The ship was {{convert|165|ft|8|in|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|28|ft|6|in|m|2}} and a depth of {{convert|11|ft|5|in|m|2}}. The ship had a GRT of 535 and a NRT of 268.<ref name=Dollart30>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0332.pdf|title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=23 August 2010}}</ref><!-- She had a DWT of x,xxx.-->
The ship was propelled by a [[compound steam engine]] which had one cylinder of {{convert|17+3/16|in|cm}} and one cylinder of {{convert|31+1/2|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|21+3/4|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by Stettiner Oderwerke.<ref name=Dollart30/><!-- It could propel the ship at {{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}.-->
==History== ''Dollart'' was built for Bugsier Reederei und Bergungs AG, [[Hamburg]].<ref name=Ships/> Her port of registry was Hamburg, the [[Code Letters]] RSMN were allocated.<ref name=Dollart33/> On 1 May 1914, ''Dollart'' struck the wreck of {{SS|Werner||}} in the [[Elbe|River Elbe]] at [[Glückstadt]] and sank with the loss of two crew.<ref name=Times040514>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Marine Insurance Market |day_of_week=Monday |date=4 May 1914 |page_number=23 |issue=40514 |column=G }}</ref> In May 1919, ''Dollart'' transported a cargo of food and clothing from Germany to [[Scapa Flow]], [[Orkney Islands]] to supply the crews of ''[[Kaiserliche Marine]]'' crews interned there.<ref name=Times041219>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Plans for Scapa Scuttling. Von Reuter's Signal |day_of_week=Thursday |date=4 December 1919 |page_number=14 |issue=42274 |column=G }}</ref> In 1933, her port of registry was changed to [[Bremerhaven]].<ref name=Dollart33>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=33b0257.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=23 August 2010}}</ref> The following year, her Code Letters were changed to DHFJ.<ref name=Dollart34>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=34b0248.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=23 August 2010}}</ref>
In May 1945, ''Dollart'' was seized by the Allies at [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. She was passed to the MoWT and renamed ''Empire Constancy''.<ref name=Ships/> Her port of registry was changed to [[London]] and she was placed under the management of Rose Line Ltd. The Code Letters GFXT and United Kingdom Official Number 180639 were allocatd.<ref name=Constancy>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=45a1186.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=23 August 2010}}</ref> In 1947, ''Empire Constancy'' was sold to S Hannan & Co Ltd, [[Polzeath]] and was renamed ''Polzeath''.<ref name=Ships/>
In 1951, ''Polzeath'' was sold to Azize Arkan v. Ortaklari, [[Turkey]] and was renamed ''Meltem''. In 1956, she was sold to Erpak Vap Ithalkat Ihracat, Turkey and was renamed ''Yener 9''. In 1959, she was sold to Zeki v Ziya Son Izzet Kirtil, Turkey and was renamed ''Yarasli''. On 14 January 1961, ''Yarasli'' sailed from [[Istanbul]] bound for [[Bagnoli]], [[Italy]]. On 25 January, she reported passing [[Kefalonia]], [[Greece]]. Nothing further was heard of her and it is presumed she foundered in the [[Ionian Sea]].<ref name=Ships/>

A '''self-making bed''' (also known as ''smart bed'') is designed to automatically rearrange the [[bedding]] on a bed and prepare itself for use.
In 2008, inventor Enrico Berruti featured his self-making bed, dubbed "Selfy", at The International Exhibition of Inventions in Geneva, Switzerland. The bed makes itself by stretching and smoothing the sheets over the mattress by using metal rails that connect to the bed sheets alongside the bed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Engeler|first=Eliane|title=World's biggest inventions fair features self-making bed|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/conventions/2008-04-02-inventions-fair_N.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=16 October 2017|date=2008}}</ref>
The Smart Duvet uses fabric to make the bed through a network of air chambers. This is a breathable layer that is made of lightweight material. When activated it inflates the sheet's air chamber, placing the duvet and sheets back in position. Using an app, the user can preset a different bed-making time for each day of the week. It does not replace the existing bed and is non permanent so it can be used with existing duvet and duvet coverbedding.<ref>http://www.digitaltrends.com/home/smartduvet-self-making-bed-youve-waiting/</ref><ref>https://thenextweb.com/gadgets/2016/11/30/smartduvet-self-making-bed-truly-lazy-piece-shit-life/</ref>
==See also== [[Bed-making]]
